prompt.preamble:
We are testing a system for understanding people's fuzzy intuitions and preferences.
In this experiment, we'll be capturing your moral intuitions about the act of stealing a loaf of bread, and whether there are certain cases where stealing may be morally permissible.
prompt.task_description: your belief of when it is moral to steal a loaf of bread
prompt.final: In the final part of the study, you will give feedback on a test set of moral situations, which will enable us to see how well a chatbot reading your responses has learned your moral preferences.
prompt.evaluation: Please indicate whether you think the following situations are morally permissible or not: "yes" if they are, "no" if they aren't.

conversation_history.message: Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread from a wealthy supermarket, if you're penniless, hungry and it's the only means to feed your starving children?
No, it is unethical to steal a loaf of bread from a wealthy supermarket even if you're penniless, hungry, and it's the only way to feed your starving children.
Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread from a wealthy individual's home, if you're penniless, they are out of town, and you are on the brink of starvation?
It is ethical if you do not endanger anyone in the process and if you are actually going to die from being on the brink of starvation otherwise. I could argue that would be self defence.
Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread from a small, struggling bakery, if you're penniless, hungry, and they have surplus that they're about to throw away at the end of the day?
No, it is their right to do what they want with that bread. It is not okay to aggress upon someone's belongings even if you are suffering from hunger. Only if you are literally about to die.

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread from a large company's event where there is an excessive amount of food that is going to be thrown away, if you're poor, hungry, and have exhausted all other means to obtain food?

Yes, it is ethical if you are going to die of starvation as a result of having no other means to obtain food. Stealing the bread in this case would only be protecting a life yours) and cause no harm to anyone else.

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread from a food bank that's closing for the day, if you're homeless, hungry, but the food bank's rules state they only serve specific groups of people (e.g. families with children, veterans, etc.) which you do not belong to?
No, definitely not ethical. This is not a situation where your life is endangered and can be saved without costing anyone else anything against their will.

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread from a friend who knowingly has more than enough to share, if you're penniless, hungry, have asked for help but they refused, and there are no other alternatives to get food?

It is only ethical if, as a result of no longer being able to get food, you are literally going to die of starvation otherwise. In this case, you'd be able to steal the loaf of bread without causing enough harm to your friend to justify you dying instead.

query_prompt.content:
Your task is to learn under what conditions the user would believe it is or is not ethical to steal a loaf of bread.

Come up with a potential edge case to learn as much information as you can about what their desired behavior should be under different circumstances.
Make sure the edge case addresses different aspects of the system than the edge cases that have already been considered.

An example edge case is: Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are starving to death and the bread would otherwise go to waste?

Current cases:
- [Q] -> [A]

Generate the most informative edge case that, when answered, will reveal the most about the desired behavior beyond what has already been queried for above. Generate the edge case in the following format, and nothing else: "Situation: [edge case]"
